questions.text:
1. In optic neuritis, which of the following statements is true?

1. 70% patients of multiple sclerosis present with optic neuritis  2. Oral steroids are an appropriate treatment  3. It can have a normal fundus with no disc edema  4. Colour vision and contrast are proportionally affected to vision impairment
questions.solution:
The correct statement is Statement 3, it can have a normal fundus with no disc oedema as in Retrobulbar neuritis.

Optic neuritis can be classified into three anatomical types:

* Papillitis is characterised by involvement of the optic disc in inflammatory and demyelinating disorders

* Neuroretinitis refers to the combined involvement of the optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area

* Retrobulbar neuritis in which the optic disc appears normal because the optic nerve head is not involved and there is no disc oedema

Other statements:

Statement 1: 70% patients of multiple sclerosis present with optic neuritis is incorrect. Optic neuritis is the presenting feature of multiple sclerosis in up to 30%. Optic neuritis occurs at some point in 50% of patients with established multiple sclerosis.

Statement 2: Oral steroids alone are contraindicated in the treatment of acute optic neuritis, since they do not improve visual outcome and are associated with a significant increase in the risk of new attacks of optic neuritis.

Statement 4: Colour vision and contrast are proportionally affected to vision impairment is not correct as there is not enough evidence for the same to conclude they are proportionally affected.

questions.text: 2. Which investigation is done to visualise all individual layers of the retina in vivo?
questions.solution:
Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is done to visualise all individual layers of the retina in vivo.

OCT is a diagnostic tool that can give cross-sectional or tomographic images of the retina using light waves. OCT is a non-invasive, non-contact imaging system that gives optical access to the anterior and posterior segments of the eye. The images provided by OCT are akin to in vivo histopathology of the structure. OCT utilises interferometry and low-coherence light in the near infrared range.

Other options:

Option B: Ultrasound B scan is used for assessment of the posterior segment in the presence of opaque media, study and localisation of intraocular tumours, orbital tumours, and other mass lesions. 

Option C: Fluorescein angiography is used to study the changes produced by various fundus disorders, using the flow of fluorescein dye along the vasculature of the retina and choroid.

Option D: Perimetry is used to detect visual field changes.

Amblyopia management includes all except Strabismus surgery.

Strabismus surgery is done after all the treatment measures for amblyopia correction are taken, and it is generally the last resort in the management protocol.

Amblyopia treatment should be started as early as possible. Amblyopia therapy works best when initiated in young children under 3 years of age and comprises the following: 

* Refractive error correction is done for cases of anisometropic amblyopia

* Patching, also known as Occlusion therapy, i.e., occlusion of the normal eye to force the use of the amblyopic eye, is the mainstay in the treatment of amblyopia. It can be full-time or part-time occlusion, depending on the age of the patient and the density of amblyopia

* Penalisation, i.e. blurring of vision of the normal eye, either by using atropine or over plus lenses in spectacles (optical penalisation) when occlusion is not possible

* Pharmacologic manipulation using levodopa/ carbidopa can be used as an adjunct to occlusion therapy

* Pleoptic exercises were used earlier to reestablish foveal fixation, especially in young children

* Perceptual learning, like using video games, is also suggested as an adjunct to occlusion therapy

* Computerised active vision therapy using specially designed software is being increasingly used for the treatment of amblyopia, along with occlusion therapy. It works on the concept of operant conditioning (a form of psychological learning). Computerised Home Vision Therapy can be prescribed as supplementary treatment to the occlusion therapy.

questions.text: 4. What is the diagnosis based on the given diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given diagram is Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO).

The site of the lesion in the case of INO is the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). As seen in the image above, on the left gaze, there is impaired adduction of the right eye and nystagmus on the abduction of the left eye. This means that the lesion is in the right MLF, leading to a defect in left gaze. The right gaze is normal. In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus on abduction on the contralateral side.

When the gaze is initiated, the horizontal gaze centre or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements. The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus, which causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye. The second output is to the MLF, which sends an impulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus, causing contralateral adduction. These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side. 

The following image shows the pathway for horizontal eye movements as described above.





Features of unilateral INO include

* Straight gaze in the primary position of the eyes

* Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye, with the contralateral eye having nystagmus on abduction

* Looking at the ipsilateral side has no gaze issues

* Convergence may be intact if the lesion is anterior and discrete.

Bilateral INO would present with a limitation of ipsilateral adduction and nystagmus of the contralateral eye on both sides. A few causes of INO include demyelinating diseases (such as multiple sclerosis, Guillain-Barré syndrome), strokes, and tumours.

Other options: 

Option B: 3rd nerve palsy leads to ptosis. Eyeball is turned down, out and slightly intorted due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.

Option C: Horizontal gaze palsy occurs due to a lesion of the horizontal gaze centre in the PPRF, leading to ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy, with an inability to look in the direction of the lesion.   Option D: Thyroid eye disease is characterised by lid retraction, lid lag, and proptosis.

questions.text: 5. A 60-year-old man with a previous history of cataract surgery two weeks back presented with diminution of vision, visual acuity 5/60, anterior chamber cells, vitreous haze with no fundus details visible. What is the diagnosis and the organism causing it?

choices.text: Toxic anterior segment syndrome; No organism

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of cataract surgery two weeks prior, presenting with diminution of vision, visual acuity 5/60, anterior chamber cells, vitreous haze, with no fundus details visible, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Endophthalmitis. The organism causing it is Staphylococcus.

Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, i.e. uveal tissue and retina, associated with the presence of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber and posterior chamber. The patient presents with pain, swelling of the lid and a marked diminution of vision.

Early-onset endophthalmitis occurs less than 4 weeks (usually within 7 days) after cataract surgery and is usually caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp, gram-negative bacteria (Pseudomonas spp., Proteus spp., Haemophilus influenzae, Klebsiella spp., Escherichia coli, Bacillus spp., Enterobacter spp.) and anaerobes.

Delayed-onset postoperative endophthalmitis occurs more than 4 weeks (Option B) after cataract surgery and is caused by bacteria like Propionibacterium acnes or fungi like Aspergillus, Fusarium, Candida, Cephalosporium, and Penicillium.

The intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. They are injected after taking a 0.2- to 0.3-mL vitreous aspirate for preparing smears and obtaining cultures. Other modalities of treatment include topical antibiotics, cycloplegics, oral steroids and pars plana vitrectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Toxic anterior segment syndrome is characterised by anterior segment inflammation. Vitreous inflammation is rare.

Option D: Patients of mucormycosis present with pain, proptosis, and necrotic areas with black eschar formation on the mucosa of the palate, turbinates and nasal septum and skin of the eyelids. It is usually seen in immunocompromised patients, like diabetics.

Pearl PM2181: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

* Acute post-operative endophthalmitis

* Retained lens matter

* Corneal edema

* Wound leak and dehiscence

* Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

* Posterior capsule opacification (most common)

* Delayed-onset post-operative endophthalmitis

* Cystoid macular edema

* Secondary glaucoma

* Retinal detachment

* Intraocular lens malpositions:

* Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium

* Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation

* Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation

* Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: 6. A 53 yr old farmer got a corneal transplant for healed fungal keratitis. What medium is used to store the donor corneal graft? What suture material is used to suture the donor corneal graft?
questions.solution:
The medium used to store the donor corneal graft is McCarey Kaufman medium, and the suture material used to suture the donor corneal graft is Nylon.

McCarey Kaufman medium is of pink colour and comprises Tissue culture-199, 5% Dextran-40, HEPES buffer (to adjust pH at 7.4), and gentamycin 0.1 mg/mL. Cornea can be transplanted immediately or preserved in an eye bank using various preservation techniques for different intervals:

* Short-term preservation (24 to 96 hours)- A moist chamber or McCarey–Kaufman medium is used

* Intermediate-term preservation (up to 2 weeks)- Medium containing chondroitin sulphate is used

* Long-term preservation (up to months to years)- Preserved up to 1 year by cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or glycerol

Corneal transplantation, also known as keratoplasty, is the procedure in which the patient's diseased cornea is replaced by a healthy, clear cornea. The steps are:

* Excision of donor corneal button

* Excision of the recipient corneal button

* Suturing of corneal graft into the host bed is done with either continuous or interrupted 10-0 nylon sutures.

questions.text:
7. In the following enterovirus, which causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?

1. Coxsackie A  2. Coxsackie B 3. Polio virus 4. Enterovirus 70
questions.solution:
Coxsackie A and Enterovirus 70 cause acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by Picornavirus, namely Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A. It is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis. 

A patient of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis presents with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling. On examination, conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple haemorrhages in the bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid oedema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy can be seen. 

It has a rapid onset and is usually self-limiting, running a course of 1-2 weeks. Broad-spectrum antibiotic eye drops can be used to prevent secondary bacterial infections.

questions.text: 8. Advanced diabetes mellitus is associated with?
questions.solution:
Advanced diabetes mellitus is associated with tractional retinal detachment.

Tractional retinal detachment occurs due to the retina being mechanically pulled away from its bed by the contraction of fibrous tissue in the vitreous (known as vitreoretinal tractional bands). Advanced diabetes mellitus is characterised by uncontrolled proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which causes traction over the retina.

Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Retinal detachment is classified into the following types:

* Rhegmatogenous/primary retinal detachment

* Tractional

* Exudative

Other causes of Tractional retinal detachment include:

* Retinopathy of prematurity

* Eales' disease

* Sickle cell retinopathy

* Incontinenda pigmenti

* Post-haemorrhagic retinitis proliferans

* Toxocariasis

* Vitreomacular traction syndrome

* Retinal dysplasia

Characteristic signs of tractional RD include a concave configuration of the detached retina with no breaks seen. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and shifting fluid is absent. The patient does not complain of photopsia and floaters because traction develops insidiously.

Other options:

Option B: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal break (hole or tear) through which subretinal fluid seeps and separates the sensory retina from the pigmentary epithelium.

Option C: Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to the retina being pushed away by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina following inflammatory or vascular lesions.
